In 1995, Brookmeyer et al. [ 72] proposed a simplistic modeling approach that uses diagnostic tests for HIV-1 p24 antigen to determine the prevalence of individuals who are p24 antigen-positive among HIV-seronegative individuals. Let μ be the mean duration of the p24 antigen-positive period before seroconversion, I be the infection risk per unit time for each uninfected individual (that is, the current incidence rate), and p be the expected proportion of individuals who are p24 antigen-positive among individuals whose HIV-antibody test results are negative or indeterminate. Then, p can be approximated as I μ, and I can be estimated as
